questions.text: A 35-year-old female was admitted to a hospital with a fracture of the femoral shaft. After 2 days, she developed breathlessness and altered sensorium. Despite aggressive resuscitation efforts, she passed away three hours later in the intensive care unit. The autopsy finding in the lung tissue is shown below. What is the probable cause of death?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The image shows fat globules in lung tissues, which are suggestive of fat embolism.
  • The fat globules may originate from bone marrow or adipose tissue. Fat embolism is more common following severe injuries with multiple fractures and fractures of major bones like the femur, pelvis and tibia.
  • Symptom Triad of fat embolism: (i)cerebral; (ii)pulmonary, and (iii) petechial rashes
  • In thecerebral type,the patient becomes drowsy, restless and disoriented and gradually goes into a state of coma.
  • In thepulmonary type,tachypnea and tachycardiaare the more prominent features.
  • The other common feature of fat embolism is a petechial rash, usually on the front of the neck, anterior axillary folds, chest or conjunctiva. If untreated, and sometimes despite treatment, the patient develops respiratory failure and dies.

Explanation of other options:

Air embolism (Option A): Sudden in onset; usually follows central line insertion or trauma involving the neck or thorax, not supported by clinical timeline or histology.

Cardiogenic shock (Option C): No evidence of myocardial infarction or heart failure; shock is secondary here.

Hypovolemic shock (Option D): Would occur early due to blood loss, not consistent with delayed presentation and histological findings.

choices.text: External fixation with serial Doppler examinations
Open reduction internal fixation using plates and screws

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presented to the casualty with fractures to both bones of the right leg after a RTA. He was splinted in the field, but on arrival to the emergency room, he complained of painful "tightness" around the leg and severe uncontrolled pain despite maximum dose analgesics. His pain is exacerbated when the toes and ankle are passively dorsiflexed. What is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient has clinical symptoms and signs of legcompartment syndromeand should undergo immediate fasciotomy followed by external fixation for fracture stabilisation.
  • Tibial fractures are among the most common reasons for compartment syndromes of the leg. A clinical assessment is key in the diagnosis of acute compartment syndrome. If there is uncertainty, intracompartmental pressure measurement has been advocated to help confirm the diagnosis.
  • 6 P's of compartment syndrome:Pain out of proportion to injury, Paralysis, Paresthesias, Pallor, Pulselessness and Pain on passive stretch.
  • We cannot perform intramedullary nailing or open reduction and internal fixation in this case because surgery itself is a predisposing factor for the development of compartment syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

External fixation with serial Dopplers (Option A): Serial Dopplers assess vascularity, not compartment pressures. This delays definitive management.

Intramedullary nailing (Option B): Contraindicated in the presence of compartment syndrome unless fasciotomy is performed first.

ORIF with plates and screws (Option C): Extensive dissection increases compartment pressure and risk of wound breakdown, not suitable before decompressing the compartments.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman is noted to have a traumatic injury to her right thigh. Which of the following is most sensitive for the diagnosis of compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Among all clinical signs of acute compartment syndrome, pain, particularly:

  • Severe pain out of proportion to injury, and
  • Pain was elicited on passive stretch of the involved muscles.
    It is the earliest and most sensitive sign.
  • Pain may precede other classical "6 Ps" (Pain, Pallor, Pulselessness, Paresthesia, Paralysis, Poikilothermia), making it crucial for early detection and prompt fasciotomy.

Explanation of other options:

Pulselessness (Option A): A late and unreliable sign in compartment syndrome. Arterial pulses may remain intact due to patent major arteries despite raised compartment pressures.

Pallor (Option B): Also a late feature and non-specific; may occur in vascular compromise, but is not the most sensitive indicator.

Paresthesias (Option D): An early neurological symptom, but it appears after pain and is less sensitive.

choices.text: Systolic pressure minus intra-compartmental pressure is less than 30 mmHg.
Diastolic blood pressure minus intra-compartmental pressure is less than 30 mmHg
Diastolic blood pressure minus intra-compartmental pressure is greater than 30 mmHg

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents to the emergency room after a motor vehicle collision, where her leg was pinned under the car for over 30 minutes. On arrival at the casualty, her BP was 80 systolic. Which of the following is the most accurate way to diagnose compartment syndrome in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The classical definition of compartment syndrome is an intracompartmental pressure of 30mm of Hg or above.
  • However, this is not true for hypotensive The best way to diagnose compartment syndrome in a hypotensive patient is to calculate the delta P value.
  • Diastolic blood pressure minus intracompartmental pressure is calleddelta p.
  • If delta p is less than 30 mmHg patient requires immediate fasciotomy for compartment syndrome.

choices.text: Mature fibroblasts are seen at the periphery and proliferating fibroblasts at the centre
Cytological atypia and mitotic figures are seen at the periphery, and a mature fibroblast at the centre
Mature fibroblasts are seen at the centre and proliferating fibroblasts at the periphery
A mature fibroblast, along with cytological atypia and mitotic figures, is seen at the periphery

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about myositis ossificans?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Myositis ossificans is a benign, self-limiting ossifying lesion of soft tissue, often occurring after trauma. It is most common in young adults and often affects large muscles (e.g., quadriceps, brachialis).
  • Histological hallmark: Zonal pattern of maturation
    • Centre: Mature fibroblasts and lamellar bone
    • Periphery: Immature, proliferating fibroblasts, sometimes resembling a sarcoma
    • This "zoning phenomenon"is diagnostic and distinguishes myositis ossificans from extraskeletal osteosarcoma, which lacks this zonation.

Explanation of other options:

Mature fibroblasts are seen at the periphery and proliferating fibroblasts at the centre (Option A): This is the reverse of the true zonation.
If the centre is more cellular and active, and the periphery is mature, it resembles the non-zonated pattern of a soft tissue sarcoma, particularly extraskeletal osteosarcoma.

Cytological atypia and mitotic figures are seen at the periphery and mature fibroblasts at the centre (Option B): This would indicate a malignant tumour, not a benign lesion. If these features were present, especially at the periphery, it would raise high suspicion for extraskeletal osteosarcoma.

Mature fibroblasts, along with cytological atypia and mitotic figures, are seen at the periphery (Option D): A mixture of maturity with atypia is atypical, and more consistent with a low-grade sarcoma or misdiagnosed malignancy.

questions.text: Which is not a complication of a Colles fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gunstock deformity

  • Also called cubitus varus deformity, it is a complication of a supracondylar fracture of the humerus, typically in children.
  • It results in medial deviation of the forearm, creating the "gunstock" appearance.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents complaining of a groin mass, which he noticed after a sports injury that occurred 1 year ago. He states that he was struck in the groin with an opposing player's helmet during a tackle and had a large amount of bruising and pain. While his pain and bruising subsided, he noticed this groin mass, and it hasn't grown and is non-tender. He is otherwise healthy. The inlet pelvis radiograph is shown in the Figure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The X-ray image shows a central lucent area with a peripheral dense area, which is a classical finding of Myositis ossificans.
  • Lipomas and synovial sarcomas can have ossification, but not in this type of pattern. (Option A ruled out)
  • Periosteal chondrosarcoma - the location of the lesion isn't on the bone but adjacent to the bone. In addition, a periosteal chondrosarcoma would have mineralisation which looked like cartilage, not bone, as in this case. (Option D ruled out)
  • Malunion would show abnormal bone alignment, not an isolated soft-tissue calcification. The lesion would be contiguous with the ischial cortex, not separate with zonal ossification. (Option C ruled out).

choices.text: Nonunion fracture lateral condyle of humerus
Malunited medial condyle fracture of the humerus

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy presents with progressive weakness in the right hand, especially involving the ring and little fingers, along with wasting of the hypothenar muscles. He also complains of numbness in the medial 1½ fingers. On probing the history, it is revealed that he sustained an elbow injury at the age of 5, which was managed conservatively. Examination reveals a cubitus valgus deformity of the elbow. A positive Tinel's sign is noted at the cubital tunnel.
Which of the following is the most likely cause of his current neurological findings?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Based on the above findings, the Diagnosis is Tardy ulnar nerve palsy.

  • Typically, tardy ulnar nerve palsy occurs as a consequence ofnon-union of a lateral humeral condyle fracturein a child, resulting in progressivecubitus valgus deformity.
  • Nonunion of the lateral condyle of the humerus in children leads to progressive cubitus valgus, which causes stretching of the ulnar nerve across the cubital tunnel during elbow flexion and extension.

This chronic traction results in:

  • Hypothenar wasting
  • Clawing of ulnar digits
  • Medial forearm and hand paresthesia

Explanation of other options:

Malunited medial condyle fracture (Option B): Rare and less likely to cause significant valgus/varus deformity, leading to nerve tension.

Elbow dislocation (Option C): May cause acute ulnar nerve injury, not the delayed-onset (tardy) variety.

Gunstock deformity (cubitus varus) (Option D): A known cause, but not the most common; occurs due to malunion of supracondylar fracture.

choices.text: Retinal changes of fat or petechiae

questions.text: What is the major criterion for fat embolism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) is a serious complication usually following long bone fractures, especially the femur and pelvis.
  • Diagnosis is often clinical and based on Gurd and Wilson's criteria, which classify findings into major and minor criteria.

The three major factors for diagnosing fat embolism according to GURD's criteria are

  1. Respiratory symptoms
  2. Cerebral symptoms and
  3. Petechial rashes.

For the major criterion, PaOâ‚‚ should be < 60 mmHg(hypoxemia ).

(Option C ruled out).

Gurd and Wilson's Diagnostic Criteria for Fat Embolism Syndrome

Major Criteria

  • Respiratory symptoms and signs (hypoxemia) with radiographic changes
  • Cerebral signs unrelated to head injury or other conditions
  • Petechial rash

Minor Criteria

  • Tachycardia over 110 beats/minute (Option A)
  • Pyrexia > 38.5°C (Option B)
  • Retinal changes of fat or petechiae
  • Renal changes
  • Jaundice
  • Laboratory findings:
    • Acute fall in haemoglobin
    • Sudden thrombocytopenia
    • High ESR
    • Fat macroglobulinemia

Diagnostic Requirement: One major and four minor criteria, plus fat macroglobulinemia, are required for diagnosis.

choices.text: Increasing deformity at the fracture site

questions.text: Which of the following is a clinical finding of nonunion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Clinical Warning Signs of NON-UNION

  • Persistent tenderness at the fracture site
  • Mild persistent mobility at the fracture site(in case not fixed)
  • Presence of persistent non-resolving oedema at the fracture and distally
  • Discomfort and pain on using the limb for moderate activities.
  • Increasing deformity at the fracture site

Radiological Warning Signs of NON-UNION

  • Persistent radiolucent line at the fracture site
  • Persistent nonremodeling external or internal or both callus(es) at the fracture site
  • Diminishing cortical thickness, somewhat increased medullary density
  • Beginning of marginal rounding of fracture ends, "woolly" bone ends.

questions.text: A 42-year-old construction worker sustains a crush injury to the hand at a job site. He immediately develops pain and significant swelling and is taken to the local emergency department for evaluation. Radiographs do not demonstrate any fracture or dislocation. On examination, he experiences severe pain with passive extension of the metacarpal phalangeal and interphalangeal joints. Otherwise, he has intact sensation and appropriate capillary refill. What is the next best step in treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation for answer:

  • All signs and symptoms show the patient is having compartment syndrome of the hand. A history and clinical exam are the best tools to identify the diagnosis, and the treatment consists of emergent fasciotomies.
  • Compartment syndrome of the hand may be secondary to trauma, burn, IV drug use, extravasation of IV fluids, or major limb revascularisation.
  • The diagnosis is usually made withpain not responding to analgesics, particularly with passive stretch of the digits. It is possible to have compartment syndrome without neurovascular changes (paresthesia, pallor, pulselessness), particularly earlier in the presentation.
  • Compartment measurements may be obtained and are considered diagnostic with an absolute value greater than 30mmHg or when the compartment pressure is within 30mmHg of the patient's diastolic blood pressure.
  • However, pressure testing is not necessary in most cases, but may be particularly important in the patient who is obtunded, intubated, or who has had a regional block, as the physical findings will be confounded.
  • There are ten hand compartments: hypothenar, thenar, adductor pollicis, four dorsal interosseous, and three palmar interosseous; andemergent surgical release of all ten compartments is indicated.

Explanation of other options:

Advanced imaging (Option A): Imaging (MRI/CT) is unnecessary and may delay urgent intervention. Not helpful in early compartment syndrome.

Arterial Doppler (Option B): Not indicated, as this is not a vascular occlusion problem. Perfusion is intact.

Admission for overnight observation (Option C): This is dangerous. Compartment syndrome is a surgical emergency. Delay can lead to muscle necrosis and permanent dysfunction.

questions.text: Volkmann's ischemic contracture mostly involves which of the following muscles?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

VOLKMANN ISCHEMIC CONTRACTURE-

  • It is a consequence of ischemic necrosis of the muscles and nerves of the forearm, which are then replaced by fibrous tissue. Any obstruction to the brachial artery caused by tight plaster, improper use of a tourniquet, or compartment syndrome can lead to Volkmann ischemic contracture (VIC).

  • Supracondylar humerus fracture is the most common fracture associated with vascular injury (Brachial artery) and is the most common cause of compartment syndrome and Volkmann's ischemia in children.
  • Volkmann ischemic contracture most commonly involves the FDP(Flexor digitorum profundus) and the median nerve.
  • Aturn buckle splint is most commonly used for mild deformities.
  • In moderate cases, the surgery of choice is theMaxpage's muscle sliding operation(erasing the common flexor origin and translating it distally onto the interosseous membrane). Severe cases require neurolysis, excision of the infarcted muscle mass and bone shortening procedures.

Explanation of other options:

Flexor digitorum superficialis (Option A): Although part of the flexor compartment, it is less commonly involved compared to flexor digitorum profundus. Superficialis is affected in more severe or extensive ischemia, but is not the hallmark muscle of VIC.

Flexor carpi ulnaris (Option B): Involved rarely; primarily functions in wrist flexion and ulnar deviation. Damage here does not produce the characteristic finger flexion contracture of VIC.

Flexor carpi radialis (Option D): Also a superficial forearm flexor; less likely to be the primary site of injury in VIC. Even if affected, the functional loss is more in wrist flexion, not the fixed finger contractures typical of VIC.

questions.text: In atrophic nonunion following a fracture, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atrophic nonunion is characterised by the absence of callus formation at the fracture site. This occurs because of the poor quality of bone fracture ends/ loss of blood supply, or infections. A bone scan will show avascular fracture ends.
  • Atrophic nonunions have to be treated using fixation and bone grafting. Bone graft will supply stem cells and osteoinductive factors, which will induce and promote bone healing.
  • Infected nonunions are usually treated using Ilizarov fixation.

Explanation of other options:

Stabilisation (Option A): Insufficient alone because there is no biological potential to heal.

Bone grafting (Option B): Without stabilisation, grafts may not be effective, as mechanical stress persists.

Distraction callogenesis (Option D): Used for limb lengthening or hypertrophic nonunion. Not suitable for atrophic nonunion.

questions.text: In hypertrophic nonunion, which of the following is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hypertrophic nonunion occurs because of inadequate immobilisation.
  • The quality of bone is very good, and union is not taking place just because of the mobility at the fracture site.
  • So a simple fixation of the fracture is enough to induce bone healing.
  • Hypertrophic nonunions are characterised by vascularized bone ends. Callus formation is generally seen and may be abundant, but this callus is non-bridging in nature. Types of hypertrophic nonunion include.
    • An elephant's foot is rich in callus, which results from insecure fixation and early weight bearing in a reduced fracture.
    • Horse's hoof-less abundant callus; it is seen in moderately unstable fracture fixation
    • Oligotrophic-minimal or no callus, but vascularized bone ends. It is seen in distracted/displaced bone ends.

Explanation of other options:

Bone grafting (Option B): Not required in a biologically active environment.

Stabilisation plus bone grafting (Option C): Bone grafting adds no benefit here and may be unnecessarily invasive.

choices.text: Anterior Compartment pressure of 25 and diastolic BP of 50mm
Anterior Compartment pressure of 25 and diastolic BP of 60mm
Anterior Compartment pressure of 20 and systolic BP of 60mm
Anterior compartment pressure of 20 and diastolic BP of 55 mm

questions.text: A 35-year-old male sustains a closed tibial shaft fracture after falling from a tree. Which of the following measurements would be concerning for an evolving compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • ΔP = Diastolic BP − Intra-compartmental pressure
  • If ΔP ≤ 30 mmHg, it indicates critical ischemia and is an indication for fasciotomy.
  • In the above question, Delta P is < 30 in option A. The Rest of all options have a delta p greater than 30 mmHg. (Options B, C and D ruled out)
  • Compartment syndrome: Compartment syndrome results when pressure rises within the closed compartment of a limb, causing a vascular compromise. Apart from limbs, it can also develop into buttocks, abdomen and paraspinal muscles.
  • The most common cause is trauma (fracture). Normal compartment pressure is below 10 mm of Hg.
  • Compartment pressure can be measured by the Wick or slit catheter technique or an arterial line pressure monitor system.
  • Prevention: The Injured limb should be kept elevated to decrease soft tissue swelling and oedema. It is important to note that in impending compartment syndrome limb should be kept at heart level because limb elevation also reduces arterial blood flow and thus oxygen delivery to tissues.
  • A supracondylar fracture humerus is the most common cause of compartment syndrome in children. Proximal tibial fracture is the most common cause of compartment syndrome in adults overall.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male is brought to the emergency department after a motorcycle accident. He has a deep lacerated wound on the thigh, which is foul-smelling, crepitant, and associated with rapidly progressing swelling and pain. The attending physician suspects gas gangrene due to Clostridium perfringens. Which toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens is primarily responsible for the myonecrosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Clostridium perfringens is the most common organism responsible for gas gangrene (clostridial myonecrosis).
  • It produces multiple exotoxins, but the alpha toxin (a lecithinase) is the most important in causing:
    • Myonecrosis
    • Hemolysis
    • Capillary leak and tissue necrosis

  • The alpha toxin acts as a phospholipase C, disrupting cell membranes and promoting widespread tissue destruction and gas production.

Explanation of other options:

Beta toxin (Option B) is seen in Clostridium perfringens type C; it causes necrotising enteritis (not soft tissue myonecrosis).

Epsilon toxin (Option C): Produced by type D strains; acts on the nervous system.

Iota toxin (Option D): Produced by type E strains; ADP-ribosylating toxin with limited role in human disease.

choices.text: Pain on passive stretch of the middle and ring fingers
Pain on passive stretch of the thumb

questions.text: The earliest feature of VIC (Volkmann ischemic contracture) is
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Volkmann's Ischemic Contracture

  • It is asequel of the missed compartment syndrome.There occurs ischemic necrosis of muscles and nerves of the forearm, which are then replaced by fibrous tissue. Any obstruction to the brachial artery caused by tight plaster, improper use of a tourniquet can also lead to Volkmann’s ischemic contracture (VIC).
  • There are four compartments in the forearm: (1) dorsal, (2) superficial volar, (3) deep volar and (4) compartment containing the mobile wad of Henry (brachioradialis, extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis). The volar (flexor) compartment is the most commonly involved compartment withflexor digitorum profundus (FDP)andthe median nervebeing the most commonly involved muscles and nerve in VIC, respectively.
  • The earliest feature of a compartment syndrome is pain on passive stretch of fingers.
  • In mild cases of VIC, only FDPs of the two or three fingers are involved.The middle and ring fingers are most frequently involved, sothe earliest feature of VIC will be pain on passive stretch of the middle and ring fingers. (The thumb is not primarily involved in the early phase of forearm flexor ischemia.) (Option C ruled out)
  • Moderate involvement: After the FDP, the flexor pollicis longus muscle is commonly involved. Other muscles, the flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS), flexor carpi radialis (FCR) and flexor carpi ulnaris (FCU) may also be involved later.
  • Typical deformity is the intrinsic-minus hand deformity (claw hand)from extrinsic muscle contracture [hyperextension at the MCP joint and flexion at interphalangeal (IP) joints]. Concomitant median and ulnar nerve neuropathy further contributes to claw hand deformity in addition to sensory changes. (Option D ruled out)
  • Severe involvement: Along with the forearm flexor compartment, extensors are also involved to a varying extent. However, the clinical picture is still that of only flexor involvement because of the strong and larger flexors. With severe cases, there are elbow flexion, forearm pronation, wrist flexion, thumb flexion and adduction, digital MCP joint extension and IP joint flexion. Skin changes occur later. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: 17-year-old high school tennis player trips while returning a serve and sustains a right mid-shaft clavicle fracture. Which of the following increases the risk of nonunion in the nonoperative treatment of clavicle fractures?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Displacement and comminution have been shown to increase the risk of nonunion in nonoperative management.
  • These features disrupt bony contact and stability, making it harder for callus formation and union to proceed predictably.

Explanation of other options:

Sling treatment (Option A): Sling is a standard conservative approach and not itself a risk factor for nonunion.

Males (Option B): While clavicle fractures are more common in males due to higher trauma incidence, nonunion risk is not significantly higher solely based on gender.

Age < 20 years (Option D): Younger age is associated with better healing potential and lower risk of nonunion.

choices.text: Ultrasound therapy to the nonunion site
Open reduction internal fixation with autologous bone graft

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient sustained a transverse humeral shaft fracture 9 months ago, for which she was treated conservatively. Presently, she complains of pain and mobility in the area of injury. A plain radiograph is shown in the Figure, and on examination, there is gross mobility at the fracture site. What is the most appropriate definitive treatment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • All Clinical findings and X-ray images clearly show non-union at the fracture site. Since it's been 9 months since the trauma, we cannot treat her with conservative options. Compression at the fracture site with bone grafting would be the best option for her, so we should do ORIF plus bone grafting.
  • Ultrasound and bisphosphonates will not be helpful in this case, as there is a clear gap between the fracture sites. (Options A and B ruled out )
  • Intramedullary nailing is ideal for diaphyseal fractures but not sufficient alone in atrophic nonunion without grafting. (Option D ruled out )

Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th ed, p. 226-227

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because she has pain in her right arm two hours after she fell in her home. Physical examination shows swelling and deformity of the right arm. The patient is unable to dorsiflex the wrist. Which of the following nerves is most likely affected by this fracture?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This clinical vignette describes the classical wrist drop occurring in association with humerus fractures due to injury to the Radial Nerve.
  • The radial nerve courses posterior to the middle third of the humeral shaft and is prone to injury with fractures of the midshaft of the humerus.
  • Sensory distribution of the radial nerve includes the first dorsal web space of the hand, and motor innervation includes the dorsal forearm extensor muscles, including those of the wrist.
  • Radial N involvement is more common in distal third humerus fractures, and such fractures associated with Radial N injury are called Holstein Lewis fracture.

Explanation of other options :

Axillary (Option A) is incorrect because this nerve is located posterior to the humeral neck. It provides sensation over the deltoid region and innervates the deltoid muscle.

Median (Option B) is incorrect because this nerve courses through the medial aspect of the arm between the biceps brachii and brachialis muscles. It provides sensation to the radial aspect of the palm and fingers as well as the distal dorsal surfaces of the thumb, index finger, long finger, and the radial aspect of the ring finger. Motor innervation within the hand includes the muscles of the thenar eminence.

Musculocutaneous (Option C) is incorrect because this nerve does not innervate any muscles involved in the motor function of the wrist or hand.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and swelling of the right knee for the past three days. Also, for the past two days, he has felt feverish. The patient is able to ambulate, but walking exacerbates the pain in his knee. Temperature is 39.3°C (102.7°F). On physical examination, the right knee is red, warm to the touch, and tender. A large effusion is noted. Which of the following diagnostic studies of the knee is the most appropriate initial step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation described is characteristic of septic arthritis of the knee The best method for confirming the diagnosis is to aspirate the knee joint to look for pus. The process of joint aspiration is also called arthrocentesis.

Explanation of other options:

Arthroscopy (Option B) is incorrect because this study is not the initial step in diagnosis.

Bone scan (Option C) is incorrect because this study is appropriate to nonspecifically localise areas of inflammation, but cannot be used to distinguish infectious from sterile processes.

CT scan (Option D) is incorrect because these studies are more sensitive for diagnosing osteomyelitis and periarticular abscesses.

questions.text: Nonunion is a common complication of all of the following fractures except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trochanteric fracture:

  • Intertrochanteric fractures occur in the extracapsular region with a rich vascular supply.
  • These fractures generally heal well, and nonunion is rare.
  • Complications are more likely to include malunion or implant failure if improperly stabilised.

Reference- Manish Kumar Varshney 1ˢᵗ edition, 510

questions.text: Which fracture among the options has the highest risk of avascular necrosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Waist of Scaphoid:

  • The most common site of scaphoid fractures.
  • The scaphoid has a retrograde blood supply from the distal to the proximal pole.
  • Fractures at the waist compromise blood flow to the proximal pole, significantly increasing the risk of AVN.
  • This is one of the classical high-risk fractures for AVN.

Explanation of other options:

Distal Scaphoid (Option B): Located near the site of blood supply entry.Low risk of AVN due to preserved vascularity.

Distal Radius (Option C): Well-vascularized bone; AVN is extremely rare in distal radius fractures unless associated with carpal bone injury.

1st Metatarsal (Option D): Also has a good blood supply, and AVN is not a common complication of fractures here.

questions.text: Which of the following is the commonest complication of external fixators?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pin tract infection is by far the commonest problem after external fixation. In addition to complications mentioned, neurovascular damage can occur while inserting the pins, and refracture can occur after removal of the fixators

  • Complications of external fixation-
    • Pin tract infection (most common)
    • Neurovascular entrapment
    • Muscle or tendon entrapment
    • Delayed union
    • Refracture
    • Cosmetic problems
    • Joint stiffness

Explanation of other options:

Ring sequestrum formation (Option B): Seen in severe or chronic osteomyelitis, and not typically associated with uncomplicated external fixators.

Loosening of the fixator (Option C): Can occur, especially if infection develops or the bone is osteoporotic. However, this is less frequent compared to a pin tract infection.

Joint stiffness (Option D): A known complication in long-term immobilisation, but less common than pin tract infection.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents 8 weeks after a distal radius fracture with a painful, swollen hand. The fracture was treated with a cast application for 6 weeks. On examination, the hand is cold & cyanosed and shiny with increased temperature sensitivity. The likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Sudeck's dystrophy is also called Complex regional pain syndrome(CRPS) or reflex sympathetic dystrophy
  • It usually happens following the injury around the wrist or foot and ankle
  • The exact mechanism is unknown; however, it is thought to be due to an autonomic dysfunction.
  • There are two types of CRPS: type 1 and type 2
  • The symptoms include continuous burning and throbbing pain, swelling, increased sensitivity to different stimuli like water, touch and vibrations and increased sweating.
  • The signs include oedema, stiffness of fingers, loss of hair, shiny skin and bluish or pinkish discolouration.
  • It can be treated with physiotherapy, and various drugs like anti-inflammatory drugs, gabapentin, pregabalin, amitriptyline, or sympatholytic drugs (Guanethidine).
  • If all these do not help, we have to give a sympathetic block.

Explanation of other options:

Median nerve injury (Opton A): reduction in temperature sensitivity is usually not seen in association with distal radius fractur,e and it also does not produce the above symptoms

Volkmann's ischemic contracture (Option B): This is a sequela of untreated compartment syndrome, presenting with fixed flexion deformities of the hand and wrist, not acute swelling or colour changes.

If compartment syndrome (Option D)were presente for 8 weeks, his hand would have gone into gangrene by now.

questions.text: Identify the sign shown in the below image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Terry Thomas sign: This is a radiological sign seen in an AP X-ray of the wrist when the scapho-lunate ligament is ruptured. In such cases, an abnormally wide gap (> 3 mm) can be seen between the scaphoid and lunate (named after British comic character Terry Thomas who had a gap between his central incisor teeth).

Reference- Manish Kumar Varshney 1ˢᵗ edition, page no 1643

Explanation of other options:

Spilt tea cup sign (Option A): Seen in posterior elbow dislocations, where the distal humerus appears displaced like a tipped cup.

Piece of pie sign (Option B): Seen in perilunate dislocation, where the lunate appears triangular or pie-shaped on AP view.

Scallop sign (Option D): Associated with neurogenic tumours in vertebrae (e.g., posterior vertebral scalloping), not wrist pathology.

choices.text: The Tavernier manoeuvre is used for closed reduction
The median nerve can get injured
Lunate remains in position, and the carpals dislocate dorsally
Lunate dislocates ventrally, and carpals remain in position

questions.text: Which is incorrect about perilunate dislocation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • InLunatedislocation, the lunate dislocates out of the carpus, while inPerilunatedislocation, the lunate stays in its place while all other carpal bones dislocate out of the carpus. (Option C)
  • In other words, in lunate dislocation long axis of the radius passes through the capitate and in perilunate dislocation long axis of the radius passes through the lunate.
  • The most common nerve injured in perilunate dislocation, as well as in fracture of the lunate is theMedian nerve. (Option B)
  • X-ray of perilunate dislocation shows discontinuity of Gilula's arc. In the lateral view of lunate dislocation, the lunate is seen palmarly rotated and no longer articulates with the capitate (Spilled teapot sign).
  • Treatment: In reducible perilunate dislocation, close reduction and percutaneous pinning are recommended. Close reduction is achieved by the Tavernier manoeuvre. For irreducible peri-lunate dislocations, open reduction and repair are required. (Option A)

choices.text: Tenderness along the course of the tendon

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the Kanavel cardinal signs of flexor tenosynovitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Kanavel's signs are a set of four clinical signs that are used to diagnose flexor tenosynovitis, a serious infection of the tendons in the fingers.
  • The four signs are:
    • Fusiform swelling of the finger. (Option A)
    • Tenderness along the course of the tendon sheath. (Option C)
    • Pain on passive extension of the finger. (Option B)
    • Flexed attitude of the finger.

Pus pointing is not a part of Kanavel signs.
